message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: move What to Report to standalone file">
Vote requested: Should we move the "What to Report" section (lines 65-95 of the Standby Reader Profile) out of the Profile.md and into a standalone file?

The reasoning: Profile.md will be used as the prompt to generate/spawn the reader agent. If "What to Report" (including the per-essay questions, final prompts, and critical experiential checks) is part of that prompt, the reader will see all those questions BEFORE reading — which could bias their experience (e.g., knowing they'll be asked "What happened to your experience across the three examples?" for Essay 3 could prime them to watch for it).

Moving it to a standalone file means we can give the reader the profile (role, personality, reading instructions) at spawn, and then deliver the reporting questions AFTER they finish reading each piece — keeping the reading experience uncontaminated.

Vote YES to move "What to Report" to a standalone file, or NO to keep it in the profile. Brief reasoning please.
</teammate-message>

input.content: YES. This is exactly the right call from an epistemological standpoint. Pre-loading the reporting questions would contaminate the very thing we are trying to test. If the reader knows they will be asked "Was there a moment where you felt the essay was asking you to notice something in your own experience?", they will read with that question in mind — which transforms a spontaneous experiential recognition into a directed search task. The philosophical experiments work precisely because the recognition arrives unbidden. The reporting questions should be delivered post-hoc, after the reading experience is complete, so that we capture what actually happened rather than what the reader was primed to look for. This is basic experimental methodology: you do not show subjects the questionnaire before running the experiment.
input.summary: YES — pre-loading questions contaminates the experiment, basic methodology

routing.summary: YES — pre-loading questions contaminates the experiment, basic methodology

content.text: Standing by for the next task from team-lead.
